content.text: Allstate is complaining about “some memory thrash/GC issues [they] suspect is a result of test calling toString on OpenAPI Generator generated POJO classes” as “OpenAPI Generator produces extremely verbose (and poorly implemented) toString that pretty prints the object”.
They are asking:
[1] Why does test invoke toString on the POJO for REST calls (in most cases this isn’t going capture the payload but rather the class name)
[2] They are considering shipping a custom template to remove the custom/generated toString but that’s going to require updates for dozens of teams.
[3] Is this something that could be disabled or tuned?

Proposed a DENYLIST with class com.allstate.productsolutions.contract.services.client.model.AgreementChangeType.toString() but they "would prefer not to have to(...) limit test’s ability to identify issues, and likely lead to false negative vulnerabilities"
Log Excerpt provided:

Based on discussion at
https://testinc.slack.com/archives/CFB0K1MTJ/p1627411248352700,
this may be a SUP or a CUST. Starting with the SUP

fields.summary: Memory Issues With Custom toString Class

content.text: we need to get this assigned and attn. can you please stress that in any Engr. calls this will heat up and I have a call on Wed. afternoon and I need someone assigned and working on this before then.
Oh Phil, thank you for grabbing this!! Allstate will be so appreciative!!! You’re the best!
What is happening is that the POJO (instance of com.allstate.productsolutions.contract.services.client.model.AgreementChangeType) is created from the tracked object of type
org.springframework.http.HttpInputMessage

and as a result a PropagationEvent is created.  When a PropagationEvent (or almost any other data flow event) is created the event records as strings the objects involved in invoking the tracked method.  The string representations are created by the method
ObjectSnapshotFactory.snapshotAndTruncate()
.  These strings are the values reported by TeamServer in the vulnerability reports.
ObjectSnapshotFactory.snapshotAndTruncate()

does truncate long object snapshot strings to reduce their memory footprint and communication message size, but it typically starts by calling the object's toString() method and this is the origin of the objectionable call.

The captured data flow events require a string representations of the objects involved in tracked method call, so there is no way to disable this functionality.  In principal, it would be possible to use a more limited String representation (like object class name along with object identity hash code) for some objects, but the agent currently does not provide the ability to configure such a behavior.

I’m going to close this as a feature request.  I think it is a feature that could be of benefit to a lot of customers that deal with transmitting large serialized object structures and are interested in reducing their impact on Assess memory usage.
cc

I wish I had better news for them.  I think adding a configuration to avoid converting large object structures to strings just to get a shortened reporting value would be a boost to agent performance, but we currently don’t have such a thing.
Sorry.
this so sucks. Do you create enhancement or does Matthias or me? Thanks BTW!

I don’t have a clear picture of the whole feature request process.  My role as the Java agent engineer on support is to review the SUP ticket and associated data to determine if it describes a bug in existing agent functionality, or if the issue can be addressed by configuration, of if addressing the issue requires adding new functionality to the agent (as in this case).
What happens after that is a mystery to me, though I think eventually the request may require approval and prioritization by
because of her role in product management.  If it passes that hurdle, I may see it again as work assigned to a Java agent developer group.
Can you shed any light on what happens with a SUP ticket determined to be a feature request?
If a SUP is marked ‘Done’, the associated support ticket gets updated with
The linked investigation ticket has been marked as Done! Please check it's status and follow the relevant steps below:
If it's "Done: Bug Confirmed" please unlink the SUP ticket and then link the corresponding test ticket.
If it's "Done: Feature Request" please file a CUST ticket accordingly, unlink the SUP ticket and then link the new CUST ticket.
If it's "Done: Functioning as Designed" please follow up with the customer or obtain further info from Engineering or Product as required.
(Thanks to Simon’s super amazing Zendesk automation)
I did create the enhancement request:

status.description: Investigation work done, no defect, CUST ticket should be opened.
status.name: Done: Feature Request
